Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Biventricular Pacing After Cardiac Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either temporary biventricular pacing or standard care

Participants.evidence: 50 adult patients at high risk of left ventricular dysfunction following cardiac surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either temporary biventricular pacing or standard care (no pacing)

Method_Outcome.evidence: VIS was assessed after cardiopulmonary bypass, after sternal closure, and 0–7 hours after ICU admission

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed

Number_Randomised.evidence: 50 adult patients... The study was conducted from April 2007 to June 2011

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the biventricular pacing group, VIS decreased... whereas in the standard care group, it increased

Result_Outcome.evidence: The difference in VIS slopes was statistically significant (p=0.02)

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group
